/***
|''Name''|TiddlyWebConfig|
|''Description''|configuration settings for TiddlyWebWiki|
|''Author''|FND|
|''Version''|1.3.2|
|''Status''|stable|
|''Source''|http://svn.tiddlywiki.org/Trunk/association/plugins/TiddlyWebConfig.js|
|''License''|[[BSD|http://www.opensource.org/licenses/bsd-license.php]]|
|''Requires''|TiddlyWebAdaptor ServerSideSavingPlugin|
|''Keywords''|serverSide TiddlyWeb|
!Code
***/
//{{{
(function($) {

if(!config.extensions.ServerSideSavingPlugin) {
	throw "Missing dependency: ServerSideSavingPlugin";
}
if(!config.adaptors.tiddlyweb) {
	throw "Missing dependency: TiddlyWebAdaptor";
}

if(window.location.protocol != "file:") {
	config.options.chkAutoSave = true;
}

var adaptor = tiddler.getAdaptor();
var recipe = tiddler.fields["server.recipe"];
var workspace = recipe ? "recipes/" + recipe : "bags/common";

var plugin = config.extensions.tiddlyweb = {
	host: tiddler.fields["server.host"].replace(/\/$/, ""),
	username: null,
	status: {},

	getStatus: null, // assigned later
	getUserInfo: function(callback) {
		this.getStatus(function(status) {
			callback({
				name: plugin.username,
				anon: plugin.username ? plugin.username == "GUEST" : true
			});
		});
	},
	hasPermission: function(type, tiddler) {
		var perms = tiddler.fields["server.permissions"];
		if(perms) {
			return perms.split(", ").contains(type);
		} else {
			return true;
		}
	}
};

config.defaultCustomFields = {
	"server.type": tiddler.getServerType(),
	"server.host": plugin.host,
	"server.workspace": workspace
};

// modify toolbar commands

config.shadowTiddlers.ToolbarCommands = config.shadowTiddlers.ToolbarCommands.
	replace("syncing ", "revisions syncing ");

config.commands.saveTiddler.isEnabled = function(tiddler) {
	return plugin.hasPermission("write", tiddler) && !tiddler.isReadOnly();
};

config.commands.deleteTiddler.isEnabled = function(tiddler) {
	return !readOnly && plugin.hasPermission("delete", tiddler);
};

// hijack option macro to disable username editing
var _optionMacro = config.macros.option.handler;
config.macros.option.handler = function(place, macroName, params, wikifier,
		paramString) {
	if(params[0] == "txtUserName") {
		params[0] = "options." + params[0];
		var self = this;
		var args = arguments;
		args[0] = $("<span />").appendTo(place)[0];
		plugin.getUserInfo(function(user) {
			config.macros.message.handler.apply(self, args);
		});
	} else {
		_optionMacro.apply(this, arguments);
	}
};

// hijack isReadOnly to take into account permissions and content type
var _isReadOnly = Tiddler.prototype.isReadOnly;
Tiddler.prototype.isReadOnly = function() {
	return _isReadOnly.apply(this, arguments) ||
		!plugin.hasPermission("write", this);
};

var getStatus = function(callback) {
	if(plugin.status.version) {
		callback(plugin.status);
	} else {
		var self = getStatus;
		if(self.pending) {
			if(callback) {
				self.queue.push(callback);
			}
		} else {
			self.pending = true;
			self.queue = callback ? [callback] : [];
			var _callback = function(context, userParams) {
				var status = context.serverStatus || {};
				for(var key in status) {
					if(key == "username") {
						plugin.username = status[key];
						config.macros.option.propagateOption("txtUserName",
							"value", plugin.username, "input");
					} else {
						plugin.status[key] = status[key];
					}
				}
				for(var i = 0; i < self.queue.length; i++) {
					self.queue[i](plugin.status);
				}
				delete self.queue;
				delete self.pending;
			};
			adaptor.getStatus({ host: plugin.host }, null, _callback);
		}
	}
};
(plugin.getStatus = getStatus)(); // XXX: hacky (arcane combo of assignment plus execution)

})(jQuery);
//}}}
*教研室公共[[Gmail|http://mail.google.com]]：guizhousim@gmail.com，密码123qweasd
*教研室的公共存储空间：[[Dropbox|https://www.getdropbox.com/]]，用公共Gmail邮箱注册，密码123qweasd
*教研室公共域名空间：gcsim.hoster3.com，ftp账号gcsim，密码123456
*[[吴建中：开放存取环境下的信息共享空间|http://catwizard.blogchina.com/1348767.html]]，编目精灵的帖子，虽然比较老了。
发信人: whisper (whisper), 信区: Wuhan
标  题: 武汉书店调查全记录
发信站: 珞珈山水BBS站 (Sun Jul 30 23:58:50 2006), 转信

两大图书城 

    ·武汉图书大世界 

    地址：江汉区黄菱路（北湖附近，新华下路与长江日报路交汇处的菱角湖畔） 

    公交：乘坐9、9专、207、519、561、601，47、69、527、604、605、621、705、803路到马场角或610、809路至黄菱路下车。

    电话：（027）85498018

    汉口北湖附近的武汉图书大世界是“华中出了名的图书城”，总面积共225亩，其中菱角湖面积180余亩，陆地面积45亩。该市场被分为卿亭路、沁园路、濡学路、文清路、紫云路。

     图书大世界的大，不是以品种齐全为标志的（约10万余种图书），它以门点多为标志（约300家），这些门点“千人一面”，经营的品种相差较小，教辅类比重较大。 在此，有“新华书店武汉图书批销中心，畅销书齐全，8折出售。大世界门口有“湖北省外文书店分店”，较小。

    ·湖北出版文化城

    位于洪山区雄楚大街268号，武汉理工大学南门对面，标志性双塔建筑。22、55、529、556、571、590、710、804路公交到图书城站下。

    自2003年4月23日“世界阅读日”开业以来，湖北出版文化城已渐渐吸引了越来越多的爱书者，形成与武汉图书大世界“隔江对垒”的独特风景。

     其一二层是就是购书中心——“湖北新华书业连锁总店”。一楼大厅陈列有《劝学》的摘选字雕：“学不可以也…….”，文化气息扑面而来。购书中心面积 2.45万平方米（有效营业面积1.6万平方米），由十大区域二十七个专业卖场和多功能厅、报告厅、读者俱乐部、荣宝斋、精品馆、茶吧、咖啡吧等十多个配套文化娱乐休闲区构成，号称目前国内规模最大、档次最高、品种最多、功能最全的现代化超级购书中心。购书中心常年陈列各类出版物近20万种，并设有期刊专区和国内知名出版社精品展示专区（鄂版书、北大版、人大版、清华版、电子工业版、科学版、机械工业版、人民教育版、高等教育版、商务版、人民文学版、三联版、中国美术版等）。

    这里每周都有英语角，常有签名售书，讲座之类的活动，《楚天都市报》上都会有预告，

      购书中心的书虽然海量，但有些书如果还是找不到，就到楼后面的“图书批发市场”看看，这个批发市场经营者和汉口的图书大世界据说基本是一样的，只是两地各开一个分店。书店里也多半教育辅导书,另外还集中着各种专业书店：医药卫生、音乐美术、建筑装饰、电子科技、社科英语等。可打八折。后排有一个“新华书店调剂特价书店”。出版城右旁边有“湖北出版物批销中心”和一些出版社的专卖区，也可零售打折。

省级系统

    由省新华书店作为控股股东的湖北新华书业股份有限公司除了出版文化城这个总店外，在“寸土寸金”的中南路上，中南商业大楼隔壁（中南路11号）一楼有“湖北新华书业中南连锁店”。 

    二楼有湖北省新闻出版局下属的的“湖北省外文书店”——（成立于1980年），由郭沫若题名，以经销外文图书音像制品为主的综合性书店。电话：（027）87815557、87822818、87822817 

    三楼有“商务印书馆武昌专卖店”。

    市新华书店系统 

    武汉市新华书店经过近几年来的股份制改造和连锁经营，综合实力不断增强。 

    服务热线800-880-9588

五大卖场 

    ·武胜路店——品种较为齐全的知名大型图书零售店。

    书店地址：汉口武胜路93号，与中山大道交叉口 服务电话：（027）83783952

    ·江汉路店——拥有四层卖场，位于江汉路步行街与中山大道交叉口。（里面非常热闹，有卖英语学习用具、电子词典、复读机、治近视的，还有放成功学VCD的，眼花缭乱。）

    乘车路线：7、24、801、608、581、2电 服务电话：（027）82832761

    ·青山红钢城店——位于青山区和平大道1534号，是一座集图书、音像、文化用品、书吧、网吧、电脑培训学校为一体的图书贸易大厦。

    乘车路线：511、542、719、807 服务电话：（027）86862947

    ·洪山街道口店——位于大专院校和科研单位之中的黄金地段，该书店有三层，以经营高教图书、外文图书为主，服务于大中专院校的读者。

    书店地址：洪山街道口 服务电话：（027）87881271

    ·武昌民主路店——位于武昌民主路201号（司门口站附近）。以教育、美术、医学三大类别图书领先的书店。

    乘车路线：14、15、521、572、515、804、529、530 服务电话：（027）88872870

专业店 

    ·武汉外文书店——2003年由原来开业仅两年多声名鹊起的大学书店“变脸”而成。一楼有音像、工具书、我读中文、大学教辅专区，二楼有外文考试、外语教材、原版图书、各类语种、四大名社（外研社、外教社、外文社、世界图书）专区。

    书店地址：洪山区四眼井64号（武汉大学出大门向前100米） 

    服务电话：（027）87211660

    · 武汉古籍书店－－其前身为1957年成立的江汉路“古旧书门市”，上个世纪70年代正式改名为古籍书店。经营品种涵盖文学、语言文字、历史、哲学、书画艺术、医农科技、综合参考等门类，“类书、丛书、版本校勘、藏书题拔、读书笔记”等一应俱全，还有一批珍稀的线装书。有桌椅、楹联、象棋……环境幽雅！

    现在的古籍书店位于江汉路书店二楼内。而武汉古籍书店“翰墨林书画社”位于交通路一侧。

    服务电话：（027）82832761

    ·商务印书馆汉口专卖店——位于江汉路新华书店交通路一侧，十平方米左右。与“翰墨林书画社”相邻。以社科、工具书为主。品种约2000种。

    服务电话：（027）82832761

    ·音像中心——位于汉口大智路34号。系全市新华书店及连锁加盟店音像制品配送中心，同时批零兼营。是一家规模大、实力强、品质高、品种多、信誉好的正版音像制品专业经营单位和发散中心。

    乘车路线：7、24、533、2电 服务电话：（027）82832651

其他

    ·即将启动运行的“光谷书城”，位于鲁巷广场旁，由武汉市新华书店和武汉光谷广场建设发展公司合资兴建的一座全国最大的科技书城。总投资8000余万元，营业面积11000平方米。

    · 市内还有很多其他新华书店连锁门市，比如：水果湖店（水果湖步行街×东一路处）、青山南干渠店、汉口车站路店（与友益街交叉口，二楼有3折特价书）、惠济路店（解放公园路75号）、二七路店、百步亭店、汉阳翠微路店（归元寺向前100米丁字路口）、江汉大学店……

    在每家新华书店里或地下层都有“音像书店”。

    ·在武昌民主路店附近还有一家新华书店“特价书店”，全场半价。出售滞销、不成套、过时的书籍，或许也能淘得几本好书。 

社科书店

    专业的社科书店除了前面已经介绍了武汉古籍书店和两家商务印书馆专卖店，下面介绍两家三联直销店，两家席殊书屋，两家湖北社科书店，两家邗江古籍书店。

    ·生活·读书·新知三联书店武汉分销店（总店） 

    地址：武昌区民主路138号，司门口东站附近，与民主路新华书店相隔不远。

    电话：（027）88840849、88871236 

    ·三联学府书店

    总店约有百平方米，学府书店十几平方米。总店后面有一个特价打折区。三联书店由毕业于武大图书馆学专业的郜定峰执掌。总店内有音乐，有桌椅，有好书，人文色彩浓重。三联人称：“书店不仅是买书的地方，更是爱书人享受的地方。三联书店应该是城市的一道风景。” 

    地址：武大大门和附中之间八一路上，武汉大学附中斜对面，广八路站附近。

    网址：http://www.whjpc.com/ 

    电话：（027）87661360

    ·席殊书屋

    总店地址：武大附中校门旁（八一路与广八路交叉口）。 电话：（027）87873292

    分店地址：中南广场购物中心六楼

    席殊书屋——招牌由汪道涵题写，是中国首家民营全国性连锁书店。实行会员制，每两月一期的俱乐部会刊《好书》杂志，专为会员推荐好书；《好书快递》作为连锁店促销杂志，其信息传递迅速、针对性强。

     在2003年，北京旌旗席殊书屋有限公司总裁席殊两度率手下精兵强将亲临武汉。对于在湖北出版文化城正式开业的前4天来汉招商之举，席殊声称纯属巧合，却坦率地承认该公司把过年之后扩大版图的第一站选在了武汉，目的就是在湖北日益白热化的书业大战中占领先机。他甚至放言：“如果说湖北出版文化城是武汉的 ‘大酒楼’，我们就要做遍布三镇的‘麦当劳’。”——但武汉只有两家席殊直营店。

    ·湖北社科书店 

    一店位于（洪山商场）广埠屯菜场三楼 。 电话：（027）87387664

    二店位于出版文化城后268-408号 

    有很多的好书，书也比较的全，设有中华书局、商务、三联等专柜，而且都是8折。

    ·邗江古籍书店

    一店位于武汉图书大世界菱湖路17号。 电话：（027）85498397 13098838354

    二店位于洪山商场（广阜屯菜场）三楼图书城。 电话：13098838354

    网址：http://www.whhjgj.com

    武汉邗江古籍书店创建于二十世纪九十年代，它是一专业从事古籍史料的收集、整理和组织出版发行业务的书店。

    在中国青年报2004年6月份的报道《保卫三联书店》中，发起人为全国40家学术书店，如贵阳西西弗、北京万圣书园、上海季风书园等。武汉亦有两家值得尊敬的书店：三联书店武汉分销店，湖北社科书店。

建筑书店

    ·建筑·人生 书局——位于华中科技大学东校区大门旁，主营建筑和旅游类书籍。

    ·同行建筑书店——华科南二门和三门间对面常青藤名苑巷子里，经营有：标志牌、公路桥梁、房地产、园林景观、建筑装饰设计、施工手册、图集规范、教材等。

    其他在中南一路省测绘局附近有“标苑建筑书店”、“同行建筑书店”等四五家建筑类书店，未到过不介绍。其中标苑建筑书店地址为中南一路66号，电话为（027）87813802。

电子书店 

    ·武汉电子科技书店——位于街道口，洪山新华书店对面，有两层。该店系武汉无线电工业学校创办。经营以计算机，通信，应用电子技术等专业特色为主。此店另外在出版文化城开有一家分店。 

    网址：wuhan.china-pub.com 电话：（027）87879661

    ·七寰书店——位于街道口（武昌珞狮北路，门牌号：珞狮路99号）。主要经营计算机类、电子信息类、大学理工科教材、教辅及研究生教材、科技工具书等。此店另外在出版文化城开有一家分店（517号）。 

    网址：www.qihuan-book.com 电话:（027）87645410 

    ·洪山科技书店——位于珞瑜路75号（群光广场斜对面），主要经营计算机类。 

音乐书店 

    ·武汉音乐学院音乐书店——武昌区解放路255号武汉音乐学院大门里。音乐书籍非常全。

    在音乐学院门口附近还有一些琴行兼营音乐书籍。

    ·武汉蓝海琴行音乐书屋——武珞路施洋烈士墓对面。

外文书店 

    除了湖北省外文书店和武汉市外文书店，在（洪山站）石牌岭路，亚贸广场隔壁有“武汉新东方书店”。外语类连锁书店，以经营英语学习书籍为主，重点销售新东方学校编著的书籍软件，兼营外研社等。

    在出版文化城批发市场内有如“武汉现代外国语言文学研究所书刊发行部”（王迈迈英语）等几家外文专业书店。

    另外在各高校附近也有小型专业外文书店，如中南财经政法大学（南湖校区）北苑的“文星外文书店”。

教育考试书店 

    ·众邦考试书店（复旦大学出版社武汉发行站）

    地址：武昌武珞路114号（阅马场站，向财大方向150米）

    网址：http://www.zbbook.com 电话：（027）88052614 

    隶属于创立于1994年的湖北众邦图书发行有限公司，以“考天下试，读众邦书”为经营口号。号称“武汉规模最大、品种最齐全的综合性考试书店”。

    ·21世纪考研书店——洪山四眼井（武汉市外文书店对面）

    服务电话：（027）87876456 87666550

     由六名在校博、硕士研究生创办的 “中国第一家专业性”的考研资料专供中心、考研住处咨询中心。在武汉的这家小小分店，它提供全方位考研服务：打折的考研书，免费查阅的招生简章、导师简介、历年专业课试题；定期举办“考研沙龙”、出版考研最新动态及考研信息，并免费赠送购书者（每周六日发放）；

    武汉大学大门口附近有“珞珈山教育书店”、“洪山教育考试书店”、“千里马考研书店”等，四眼井处有“21世纪考研书店”。 

    华中科技大学南二门对面有“高等教育考试书店”；南三门里有“万声书店”，外有两家“学子书店”。校内诸如图书馆内和食堂附近都有一些书店。

    华中师范大学东门卓刀泉路上有“智能书店”等两三家、湖北大学西门附近有“楚风”等五六家小书店，以经营考试辅导书和畅销书为主。

经济法律书店

    中南财经政法大学首义校区大门旁一排书店，多经济法律类：“武汉华苑教育书店”、“武汉正中财经书店”、“楚光财经书店”、“蓝天书店”、“立信会计书店”、“众邦考试书店”、“继红（湖北）法律书店”、“武汉市财经书店”等。

    ·继红法律书店（湖北法律书店） 

    地址：武珞路114号（阅马场站往东走约250米，中南财经大学门口附近） 

    网址：http://www.bookslaw.com 电话：（027）88047929，87889186，13807135080

     “凡你所需的法律专业书在此基本都能买到，凡在此买不到的法律图书其他书店也一定没有。作为中南地区最大的法律书籍专营店和全国各法律专业出版社的特约经销单位，曾先后被评为武汉地区信誉良好书店，九九年更获全国法律图书状元奖。书店到书时间快，存货量大，并代办邮购业务及电话预订，市内免费送货上门，有问题的书籍不限时间包退包还。”

    湖北法律书店在中南财经政法大学（南湖校区北苑）和武汉大学（大门左150米）开有分店。

    另外中南财经政法大学首义校区大门对面有一家“中国化工书店”。

大学出版社服务部

    ·武汉大学出版社读者服务部书店 

    地址：武汉大学正门口 电话：（027）87682718 87682427

    以经营武汉大学出版社的教材为主。凡是武汉大学出版社近5年左右出版的经济、法律、历史、外语及自然科学教材，都可在这家书店找到，享受9折优惠！假如你想找一本近年武大出版的教材而又担心徒劳而返，不妨打个电话过去咨询咨询，以免费车舟劳累之苦。

    ·广雅书社（华中科技大学出版社读者服务部） 

    位于华科东校区侧门旁；主校区内大学生活动中心旁也有一家读者服务部。兼营其他理工科技类教辅书。

    ·利群书社（华中师范大学出版社读者服务部） 

    利群书社是由革命领袖恽代英1920年与林育南等人创办，以传播马克思主义。最初在民主路附近，后来在华师北门，现已搬迁至校内“田家炳教育书院”楼下（桂北路一侧）。门上招牌由陆定一题写。现在的利群书社号称百年老店，经营却并不好。有不少三四折的特价书。

    电话：（027）87673246

旧书店/市场 

    新书有新书的新鲜，旧书有旧书的趣味。渴求知识的读者，固然让大大小小的书店里人潮澎湃，而街头巷尾的旧书摊上也是暗流涌动。

    ·泰宁街旧货市场 

    位于江汉路步行街北端（靠近京汉大道），是武汉有名的和最大的旧书市场，旧书摊最多能有三四十家，双休日开市；平时也有两三家旧书店开门；在两边的保成路、南京路上还有两处旧书摊。

    旧书和杂志之外，还有各种旧玩艺：老唱片、像章、纪念章币、文革文物、老电子产品等，有时街道中飘荡着戏曲唱片的声音，真是老汉口，老得有文化。

    街道上还有许许多多杂七杂八的东西，卖衣服的，卖碟片的，还有人卖显微镜。

    ·武汉收藏品市场（武汉集邮市场） 

     崇仁路92号，地处崇仁路×中山大道路口东北角。摊位众多，各类收藏品都有：文革书画像章、连环画、烟盒纸、陶瓷、书画、电话卡、邮票等。价钱不消说，物美价不廉。这里的书不仅是旧书，更是文物了，不是阅读学习的，而是收藏的。此处多次举行连环画拍卖会，在全国有一定知名度。

    ·欧亚达东园艺术广场 

    位于长江二桥东徐东大道，凯旋门广场对面的家居博览中心后面。徐东路站附近。

    卖旧书的店面只有三四家，旧书似乎并不多。但市场里还经营有古玩、书画、奇石、根雕、收藏品、工艺品、水族、花鸟、盆景等，很有趣味。

    其他较为集中的有名的旧书店分布在武大正门前四眼井、省图书馆阅马场、汉阳归元寺附近： 

    ·四眼井的武汉市外文书店隔壁小巷内有一家“集成旧书社”。 电话：（027）87887415

    约80平方米大的书店，虽说藏在深巷里，但“酒香”就不怕没生意。此店成立于1988年，门口有一牌子“武汉旧书集散地”。在所有的旧书店中这家是最整齐的，一排一排架子，说有二万余册旧书，种类多。

     这里的老板爱动脑筋，“精得很”或者“黑得很”，他了解新书上市的动态。“即将淘汰的书他会以极低的价卖出，再不收购。而具有保留价值的书籍，他则咬准价不放——七至八折不还价。眼光准，及时补充新鲜血液，使集成旧书社立于不败之地。”这里的书价比别处普遍高一折。

    集成社隔壁巷子里也有两家旧书店：“博文旧书店”和“治宙古旧书坊”（分店）。面积较小。后者有些画册、画报比较有趣，但价高。

    马路对面有一家“二楼旧书店”，无甚多书，多教辅类。

    ·阅马场省图书馆门口西有“求知”、“红楼”、“治宙”、“治智”等四五家不错的旧书店，只是店面狭小。

    中南财经大学天桥处有“武汉珍宝旧书城”，其实是很小的一家店。财经类较多。财大门口向右还有两家旧书店：“苦舟”和“博海”，多教辅。

    ·归元寺门前百米处有“沧海古旧书店”，好书不少但较贵，店面局促。

     附近在连接汉阳大道和翠微路的小街上，有“新茂书屋”等三家旧书店/特价书店，位于翠微小商品市场对面。这里的旧书多为人文社科类。有两家兼营特价书，对折（可以4.5折）优惠。特价书的印刷看起来和正版书差不离，品种多为品位和定价双高的计算机、经管、人文社科历史等类型，比如中国青年版及中央文献版的《毛泽东传》、傅雷译作的插图版《巨人三传》和《世界美术名作二十讲》、山东画报版的《剑桥中国插图史》、机械工业版的“计算机科学丛书”、萨缪尔森的《经济学》等畅销好书。很值得推荐。（这里的老板说是正版书，由于进货渠道的不同价钱就低了——至于什么渠道老板则缄口不言。）

    ·大东门长春观与十五中之间有一“红楼古旧书社”。地理偏僻，店面狭小。有耐心就来这里淘，上世纪后半叶的文史类图书较多。

    ·汉口航空侧路上，与航空路交叉口的“航空路站”附近（在天桥附近的中国邮政对面）有一“博览书店”，专卖旧书刊，书的种类多、品相好，在此曾购得不少书。

    ·其他在京汉火车站旁边有两三个旧书摊；在汉口长江二桥附近黄浦路上工农兵站对面有“刘氏古旧书店”，书多而杂乱。

    · 其他各大学附近也有不少旧书店，旧的教材、参考书之类的狼藉市上。如华中科技大学正门斜对面的“喻园旧书店”和东校区的“文星书店”、“喻园旧书店（分店）”，以理工科技、英语为主；中南财经政法大学南湖校区西苑有“仕林”、“良友”等五六家家旧书店，北苑南苑里也各有两家，以各类教材辅导书为主，经济法律类稍多；武汉理工大学南门天桥处（出版文化城侧）的“雄威”、“博海”两家旧书店，主营教辅。而湖北大学西门前的“文汇书社”则有不少文史类书。 
卡巴：KV3VT-TK1QX-FS92R-5R5M3

*[[Quintura|http://quintura.com/]]：搜索引擎
*[[Wikiseek|http://www.wikiseek.com/]]：专用wikipedia搜索引擎
*[[Windows Live Academic|http://academic.live.com/]]
*[[Google Scholar|http://scholar.google.com/]]
*[[Technorati|http://www.technorati.com]]
*[[Scirus|http://www.scirus.com]]
*[[citeseer|http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/cs]]：学术搜索工具之一
*[[clusty|http://clusty.com/]]
*[[PODZINGER|http://www.podzinger.com/]]，一个播客搜索引擎。
*[[与OA资料有关的搜索引擎]]
*[[Qwika|http://www.qwika.com/]]：一个专用的wiki搜索引擎
*[[J-Gate|http://j-gate.informindia.co.in/]]：电子期刊网关，包含7个学科，有 Library & Information Sciences
*[[airtightinteractive|http://www.airtightinteractive.com/projects/related_tag_browser/app/]]，搜索flickr图片的工具
*[[WikiWax|http://www.wikiwax.com/]]：一个专用的wikipedia搜索引擎。
*[[Sphere|http://www.sphere.com/]]：刚刚推出的blog搜索引擎
*[[Ixquick|http://www.ixquick.com/]]：一个mata search engine，有中文界面
*[[Google.vc|http://www.google.vc/]]：一个非官方的google站点，资源整合还不错。
*一个访问google的blogger的站点：http://www.pkblogs.com 
*[[OCLC的全球搜索Worldcat|http://worldcat.org/]]
*[[Dict线上字典]]
*[[金山词霸取词界面]]
*[[一个留言本服务：布鲁马留言本|http://gb.bluemask.net/main.php]]：可以定制代码用于自己的主页
*[[社科院图书馆|http://www.lib.cass.org.cn/index.jsp]]
*一个视频下载站点：[[KeepVid|http://keepvid.com/]]
*在线四角号码查询站点：[[deepso|http://www.deepso.com/test/code.asp]]
*查询汉字读音：[[汉字读音表|http://www.dffy.com/tool/hzpy.htm]]
*OCLC的图书检索：[[WorldCat]]
*[[Adobe flash palyer帮助和设置地址|http://www.macromedia.com/cn/]]
*一个不错的搜索站点：[[thefreedictionary|http://www.thefreedictionary.com/]]
*[[web2rss|http://www.baekdal.com/web2rss/]]：几乎所有不提供feed订阅的网站自动生成feed，方便我们的订阅。只要输入你想订阅的网站的URL即可。
*[[Gliffy|http://www.gliffy.com/]]：是一个提供在线制作流程图服务的网站。
*在线画图的网站：[[cumulatelabs|http://www.cumulatelabs.com/draw/draw.html]]
*[[在线邮票生成|http://bighugelabs.com/flickr/frame.php]]，可惜没有中国的邮票
*与flickr结合mashup个人照片的站点：[[dumpr|http://www.dumpr.net/]]
*[[有道|http://blog.yodao.com/]]：又一个搜索引擎，搜blog比较好
*比较各种wiki的站点[[wikimatrix|http://www.wikimatrix.org/]]
*[[突破封锁的方法|http://internet.solidot.org/article.pl?sid=07/09/04/0750208&from=rss]]


*Howard Rheingold的[[《The Virtual Community》|http://www.rheingold.com/vc/book/]]全文

*Peter Kollock 的[[《The Economies of Online Cooperation:Gifts and Public Goods in Cyberspace 》|The Economies of Online Cooperation.mht]]全文。（[[来源|http://research.microsoft.com/vwg/papers/KollockEconomies.htm]]）
[[黄色阶梯渐变色]]

@@color(#ffff11):范例颜色@@ 
@@color(#ffff00):范例颜色@@ 

*[[关于Book Industry的一些统计数字]]

*一篇探讨blog用于数字参考服务中的文章：[[Collaborative Reference Work in the Blogosphere|Pomerantz-Preprint-RSR-2006.pdf]]，来源：http://dlist.sir.arizona.edu/1280/01/Pomerantz-Preprint-RSR-2006.pdf

*IFLA的一份机构存储的研究报告，有一个最新（截至2006年3月1日）目录，附链接：[[Directories of Institutional Repositories: Research Results & Recommendations|151-Oliver_Swain-en.pdf]]，来源：http://www.ifla.org/IV/ifla72/papers/151-Oliver_Swain-en.pdf

*一篇information commons的综述文章：[[Reactions to the Enclosure of the Information Commons: 2000-2004|campbell.html]]，[[来源|http://www.asis.org/Bulletin/Oct-05/campbell.html]]
*[[中国信息年鉴|http://www.cia.org.cn/index.htm]]：包括大量国外、国家和地区的信息化发展的文件等内容。
*[[What’s Going on at the Library of Congress?|AFSCMEWhatIsGoingOn.pdf]]。美国国会图书馆的动向所预示的发展趋势。还有[[相关的评论|http://subjectobject.net/2006/07/23/serendipitous-browsing-a-summary-and-commentary-of-thomas-manns-whats-going-on-at-the-library-of-congress/]]

*美国一篇[[Library2.0的硕士论文|michaelhabib.pdf]]：''Toward Academic Library 2.0: Development and Application of a Library 2.0 Methodology''（[[来源|http://hdl.handle.net/1901/356]]）

*维基百科里面的[[剽窃问题|http://www.wikipedia-watch.org/psamples.html]]

*[[The Google Divide|http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6379527.html]]

*图书馆观点上的文章：[[OPAC 書目接受書評之實例|http://libraryviews.blogsome.com/2006/05/25/337/]]
从今天起，密码所谓的有符号是指有一个符号，原来的有符号是按照原来的设置。今天改了邮箱的密码，只有一个符号了。
[[基于知识生态的Web2.0信息服务（撰写）]]
!记录撰写的每一步
<<tabs tabsClass
短小灵感 '随时记下一些想法' 基于知识生态的Web2.0写作随感
正规章节 '比较正式的写作' 基于知识生态的Web2.0正式写作
>>

A [[SiteIcon|SiteIcon tiddler]]@glossary helps provide some identity to your space.  Ideally it'd be a square and a minimum of 48*48 pixels size.  You can upload your site icon using the uploader below.

<<binaryUploadPublic title:SiteIcon>>
*OPAC看来是需要改革了，有人的帖子标题就是“[[OPAC Envy]]”（OPAC嫉妒的对象），其中推荐的是一个不错的综合性搜索工具[[InfoSoup|http://www.infosoup.org/]]，能够搜索图书、电影、音乐以及电子书等等。

*美国图书馆界由Library Journal弄的[[Library Journal 2006 Movers and Shakers|http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6312521.html?display=LJMS&pubdate=3%2F15%2F2006]]好像值得关注一下，Movers and Shaders应该怎样翻译呢？
<html><object width="425" height="355"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/sjeacH8XMU8&rel=1"></param><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/sjeacH8XMU8&rel=1" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" width="425" height="355"></embed></object>
</html>
<html>
<object width="425" height="355"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/W5rk3O_RnXg&rel=1"></param><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/W5rk3O_RnXg&rel=1" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" width="425" height="355"></embed></object></html>
*在[[幻灭|http://www.kenwong.cn/post/google-has-an-official-chinese-name.html]]那里听说：“Google可能会收购中国的图书馆以推出数字化图书服务；CEO说，Google.cn的推出是“绝对正确的一步”，老米那里的librarians担心的事情要降临到chinese librarians头上了，呵呵，作为Google fans，同时又在学习library science的我心中还是有点复杂的。:( or :)
<html><object width="425" height="355"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/kJu27Ewvn_c&rel=1"></param><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/kJu27Ewvn_c&rel=1" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" width="425" height="355"></embed></object></html>
今日买了几本书：
#搜（The Search）/（美）约翰.巴特利（John battelle）著.-中信，2006.1
**其实该书英文原版还有个副书名：“how Google and its rivals rewrote the rules of business and transformed our culture”，不知道为什么中文版完全没有显示这个副书名？
#毕竟是同行，国内的百度的书也在2006.1出版了：相信中国：寻找.百度在沉静中称为亚洲最大网站的秘密（不知道这是不是副标题？版权页上没有列出，只是封面列出了）.-长江文艺，2006.1
**该书应该是百度引进的凤凰卫视的人才梁冬的重要成绩，看得出梁冬是在把百度当作媒体在做，粗翻了一下，感觉应该算是李彦宏的半个传记才对。这书要和上面那本“搜”对照着看。
**看到现在市面上越来越多的“企业成长史”一类的书籍，蓦然回首想起当年陈惠湘的《联想为什么》产生的效应，不能不感叹时代变化之快，如今对很多同类的书籍都没有什么感觉了。
#客观知识/（英）卡尔.波普尔.-上海译文，2005.9
**被诸多人士引用当作本学科理论基础的“三个世界”理论的发源地，首先当作资料藏书收藏。
#新教伦理与资本主义精神/马克斯.韦伯.-陕西师大，2006.2
**最早看到的是三联的版本，绝迹很久之后陕西师大02年出了一个彭强、黄晓京翻译翻译的版本，现在这个比之把100多页的注释加了进去，也用了原来三联版于晓等的译本。（好坏自有人说，吸收全在自己把握）
#20世纪思想史/（英）彼得.沃森.-上海译文，2006.1
**巨厚的的一本书，对于这种砖头模样的书一般还是有点恐惧的，不过在书店翻阅了半天还是被它吸引了，作为书籍爱好者，这其实就是一本20世纪名著史，因为它的行文基础就是那些有影响力的书，从世纪之初弗洛伊德的《释梦》开始一一道来，其中不乏我们熟悉的人物与书名：劳伦斯《儿子与情人》、斯宾格勒《西方的没落》、艾略特《荒原》、金斯堡《嚎叫》贝尔《后工业社会的来临》和《资本主义文化矛盾》、奥威尔《一九八四》、桑塔格《反对阐释》、罗马俱乐部《增长的极限》、R.本尼迪克特《菊与刀》（还记得新概念四册上有篇文章就是这位人类学家写的呢）.......研究书史的过程就是探询思想史的经历。该书原版是2001年出的。

[img[http://msig.info/web2v2/(reflect)GinGerBETA.png]]
[img[http://msig.info/web2v2/(reflect)GinGer.png]]
<html><img src="http://msig.info/web2v2/(reflect)GinGer.png" alt="Generated Image" /></html>

</div>
<script src="/bags/common/tiddlers/backstage.js"></script>
<script src='/bags/common/tiddlers/jquery.js'></script>
<script src='/bags/tiddlyspace/tiddlers/chrjs'></script>
<script src='/bags/common/tiddlers/chrjs.space'></script>
<script src='/bags/common/tiddlers/chrjs.users'></script>
<script src='/bags/common/tiddlers/chrjs.identities'></script>
<script src="/bags/common/tiddlers/jquery-ui.custom.js"></script>
<script src='/bags/common/tiddlers/jquery-form.js'></script>
<script src="/bags/common/tiddlers/siteiconupload.js"></script>
<script src='/bags/common/tiddlers/ts.js'></script>
<script src="/status.js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript">
/*
 * jQuery UI Autocomplete HTML Extension
 *
 * Copyright 2010, Scott González (http://scottgonzalez.com)
 * Dual licensed under the MIT or GPL Version 2 licenses.
 *
 * http://github.com/scottgonzalez/jquery-ui-extensions
 */
(function( $ ) {

var proto = $.ui.autocomplete.prototype,
	initSource = proto._initSource;

function filter( array, term ) {
	var matcher = new RegExp( $.ui.autocomplete.escapeRegex(term), "i" );
	return $.grep( array, function(value) {
		return matcher.test( $( "<div>" ).html( value.label || value.value || value ).text() );
	});
}

$.extend( proto, {
	_initSource: function() {
		if ( this.options.html && $.isArray(this.options.source) ) {
			this.source = function( request, response ) {
				response( filter( this.options.source, request.term ) );
			};
		} else {
			initSource.call( this );
		}
	},

	_renderItem: function( ul, item) {
		return $( "<li></li>" )
			.data( "item.autocomplete", item )
			.append( $( "<a></a>" )[ this.options.html ? "html" : "text" ]( item.label ) )
			.appendTo( ul );
	}
});

})( jQuery );

/***
_accounts application specific javascript
***/
var link;
ts.init(function(ts) {
	if(ts.user.anon) { // redirect to homepage when user not logged in
		window.location = ts.getHost();
	} else if(ts.user.name === ts.currentSpace){
		initSiteIconUpload(ts.user.name);
	} else {
		link = $("<a />").attr("href", ts.getHost(ts.user.name) + "/_account").text("Change User Icon");
		$("#siteiconArea div").empty().append(link);
	}
	$(".hostSuffix").text("." + ts.getHost("").split("//")[1]);
	ts.getSpaces(function(spaces) {
		$("<div class='info' />").text("You have " + spaces.length + " spaces.").insertBefore($(".spaceSearch")[0]);
		$("form.spaceSearch input").autocomplete({
			html: true,
			source: function(req, response) {
				ts.getSpaces(function(spaces) {
					var selected = [];
					for(var i = 0; i < spaces.length; i++) {
						var space = spaces[i];
						if(space.name.indexOf(req.term) > -1) {
							var host = ts.getHost(space.name) ;
							var img = host + "/SiteIcon";
							selected.push({
								value: space.name,
								label: '<a href="' + host + '" target="_parent" class="autocompleteLink"><img src="' + img + '" style="height:24px;width:auto;max-height:24px;max-width:24px;"/>' + space.name + '</a>'
							});
						}
					}
					response(selected);
				});
			},
			select: function(event, ui) {
				window.top.location = ts.getHost(ui.item.value);
			}
		});

		var $ul = $('.ts-space-search');
		$.each(spaces, function(i, space) {
			$ul.append($('<li/>').html($('<a/>').attr('href', space.uri)
				.text(space.name)));
		});

		$('form.spaceSearch button').click(function(ev) {
			$('.list-container').slideToggle('fast');
			ev.preventDefault();
			return false;
		});
	});
});

if(window != window.top) {
	$("html").addClass("iframeMode");
	$("a").live("click",function(ev) {
		$(ev.target).attr("target", "_parent");
	});
}
</script>
<!--[if lt IE 8]>
<script type="text/javascript" src="/bags/common/tiddlers/json2.js"></script>
<![endif]-->
</body>
</html>
!环境变化后，个人首先要想到的是不要去计算自己将失去什么，而是要去考虑自己能够贡献什么。
以职称评定为核心目标，积极撰写文章，出版专著，申请课题
*2006年颁发的贵州省[[职称评定文件|guizhouzhicheng.mht]]
 
<html>
<form method="get" action="http://www.iciba.com/search"
target="_blank">
<b>金山词霸</b>
<input name="s" id="s" type="text" size="21" style="height:18px;"
accesskey="c" title="查词热键:alt+c" /> <input type="submit"
value="搜 索" style="padding:3px 5px 0 5px;margin:0 0 0
10px;font-weight:bold" /></form>
</html>


<html><iframe src="http://worldcat.org/searchbox/searchbox.jsp?ai=whu_ginger318" name="wcsearchframe" scrolling="no" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" frameborder="0" style="width: 150px; height: 130px;"></iframe></html>
*[[OCLC出版物|http://www.oclc.org/asiapacific/zhcn/research/publications/default.htm]]，从1970年至今的一份目录，绝大部分都有链接。

*一个图书馆学的学科信息网关：[[infolibrarian.com|http://www.infolibrarian.com/index.htm]]，有点价值，相比较而言，国内同仁还真需要努力呢，他们的自我介绍这样说：
**We are a group of professionals working in the area of library and computer fields. Our objective behind this project is to give maximum information to working library and information science professionals, teachers and students at one place. Here, we have made an attempt to collect information from different sources and given brief description, wherever possible.
ColorPalette
StyleSheet
SiteSubtitle
GettingStarted
SiteTitle
MainMenu
SiteIcon
DefaultTiddlers
ViewTemplate
PageTemplate
SideBarOptions
EditTemplate
SiteInfo
SideBarTabs
ToolbarCommands
个人信息管理的目的是为了自己，不是为了别人。这种做法如何与2.0时代的理念相协调呢？有时候有种感觉现在很多人添加del.icio.us、弄365key、甚至连写blog的目的都是为了给别人看，其中固然有着强调2.0共享的精神在里面，但是不经意间却忘记了自己最根本的目的，因为毕竟不是每个人都是做媒体的，我们的初衷是为了满足自己的网络信息需求。
del.icio.us和365key网摘这样的东西从个人信息管理的角度看，对于个人而言最重要的方面是通过某个网址的收藏“意外地”去发现一些与你有着同样兴趣、爱好或者专业的人，并进而去了解一下这些人的收藏，看看其中是否还有些你自己同样感兴趣却还没有收藏到的网页。所以本质上del.icio.us这样的东西首先是一个个人信息渠道，其次才是它的交互性（并不是每个人都会主动去交往的，有些人甚至连被动的交往都不热衷，那么我们就能下断言这类人会被2.0时代所淘汰么？）。当个人的del.icio.us或者365key数量比较少的时候，还可以说对于个人具有信息资源管理的价值，但是，当所收藏的数量成千上万以后呢？你真的还能快速有效的从你那庞大的收藏中找到具体的某个东西吗？当然，你会说，不是有tag么？可是tag这样的Folksonomy模式对于精细化的个人信息管理价值有多大呢？这还是一个问题！

看了梁冬关于百度的书《相信中国》，对其中关于竞价排名的一段很有点想法：2002年的时候，我就写了一篇文章《竞价排名－－中小企业的营销机会》，算是比较早的介绍了百度的竞价排名，可惜文章投出去因为编辑部要求500元的版面费，反正当时并不缺少这一篇文章，也就没有再管它了，现在想想，当时要是能公开发表出去，兴许也能凭此去当时并不太有名的百度寻个兼职什么的，说不定也能捞上点百度的期权呢，哈哈。
The title and subtitle of your space are visible to visitors and are also displayed in your browser's tabs. Click on the SiteTitle and SiteSubtitle tiddler links below to make changes.
* [[SiteTitle]]
* [[SiteSubtitle]]
*Amazon静悄悄的[[A9搜索引擎|http://a9.com]]好像越来越厉害了，非常值得注意，近日它也推出了和Google一样的基于搜索结果的bookmarks，但是这种基于搜索结果的书签真的好么？也许是用del.icio.us久了，我的书签绝大部分都不是通过搜索得到的。我在a9注册了帐号，用户名：ginger

*the 2006 Computers in Libraries Conference(CIL)会议就要举行了，[[Meredith Farkas|http://meredith.wolfwater.com/wordpress/]]弄了一个[[会议wiki：cil2006|http://cil2006.pbwiki.com/]]
**另外从[[Meredith Farkas|http://meredith.wolfwater.com/wordpress/]]发现了一个不错的关于图书馆的wiki，[[Library Success: A Best Practices Wiki|http://www.libsuccess.org/index.php?title=Main_Page]]——This wiki was created to be a one-stop-shop for great ideas and information for all types of librarians. 我的用户名是ginger

*一个全力关注tag的人的blog：[[You’re It!——a blog on tagging|http://tagsonomy.com/]]，如果我要研究tag的话，这个地方需要收藏。

*Mathews, Brian的一篇图书馆参考咨询的文章：[[INTUITIVE REVELATIONS: THE UBIQUITOUS REFERENCE MODEL|IntuitiveRevelations.pdf]]。（来源：http://smartech.gatech.edu/handle/1853/8446）
>@@color(green):'' Instead of trying to make your library seem cool, be a librarian and do cool things.''@@
>Libraries are facing an ongoing existential dilemma, questioning their own significance and identity. There is much concern about the future of the profession. However, there is also much enthusiasm and a conscious effort toward developing new roles and altering services to meet patron expectations. This paper presents a new approach toward interacting with users, moving beyond the traditional barriers and seeking to deliver assistance intuitively before the patron recognizes the need.
*google今天推出了公历和农历的对照查询，例如，只要在搜索框内输入：公历2006年03月21日，敲击回车即可看到相应的农历对照：农历 二零零六年二月廿二	丙戌 狗，还有一个生肖图像呢，[img[dog|http://www.google.com/images/lunar/lunar_animal_11.gif]]，再看看我鸡年的生肖像：[img[cock|http://www.google.com/images/lunar/lunar_animal_10.gif]]

*一个互联网档案网：http://www.archive.org/， 能进行很多网站的今昔对比，例如我们查到的百度公司在2000年6月的页面，虽然好多图像没有显出了，不过主要内容还是出来了，看得出[[它也有些好玩的地方|http://web.archive.org/web/20000606160410/http://www.baidu.com/]]：
***百度公司（Baidu.com, Inc.）结合世界级先进网络技术、中国语言特色和中国互联网发展现状，全力开发中国互联网软件基础设施技术平台，提供互联网应用软件核心技术支持，直接服务于ICP、ISP和电子商务网站，进而共同为终端用户最大可能的带去方便、准确与快捷,''百度公司总部设于硅谷，在美国硅谷及北京均有其全资子公司''，她是中国最优秀的互联网络技术提供商之一，也是您互联网络事业不可缺少的伙伴。
***5月18日 北京消息：作为中国最早的ASP厂商之一的百度在线网络技术（北京）有限公司今天宣布其第一代产品--百度中文搜索引擎已经被国内著名的IT类垂直网站硅谷动力（China Enet）采用，并且于即日起在Enet网站开始全面为网络用户提供服务。
**当初他们确实是把自己定位在ASP上的，只提供互联网络技术，后来的转向现在看来还是相当英明的。不过当初它真的总部在硅谷？算是什么总部呢？^_^，看来刚出道多少都要吹嘘一点才行啊。
**看了梁冬写的百度的书，总体感觉还是不错的，至少能让普通人对百度更有好感。书中不时显示出作者在电视台当“娱乐串串烧”主持人的俏皮风格，关于自己离开凤凰那一章的描述也还算诚恳。

*一本新的专业OA杂志[[Educators’ Spotlight Digest|http://www.sosspotlight.org/?t=14]]，主要内容是关于信息素养方面的。

*又发现的一个搜索引擎：[[clusty|http://clusty.com/]]，号称“集群搜索”（clusty），可以进行个性化设置，最近针对科研教育机构也向google一样提供了相应的代码让你在自己的站点添加clusty的搜索框，不过要求的后缀是.org .edu. .net等等。（钱涂的地儿可以用用了）

*******[img[clusty|http://clusty.com/images/logow128.png]]

*一篇文章[[Library science meets business|http://www.researchinformation.info/rifebmar06profile.html]]

*美国总统布什说：National Commission on Libraries and Information Science (NCLIS)将要合并入the Institute for Museums and Libraries (IMLS)，并且他们目前的National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) programs for public and state library surveys 也要并入IMLS，据称这样可以加强联邦图书情报的政策成效并提升国家在国内外图书馆趋势方面的研究能力（will strengthen federal library and information policy efforts and enhance our nation's research capacity on domestic and international library trends.）

*一个上传免费影像文件的站点[[Direct to GUBA |http://upload.guba.com/index.do]]，不限制文件大小，推荐200M。我用ginger318@gmail注册了。不过关键的问题是速度，上传和下载速度。

*十七号介绍的[[CenSEARCHip|http://homer.informatics.indiana.edu/censearchip/]]今天看见有人用来对比测试google在中国的过滤情况（[[Online tool reveals Google’s censoring of Chinese search results|http://www.pandia.com/sew/188-online-tool-reveals-google%e2%80%99s-censoring-of-chinese-search-results.html#more-188]]），应该是个不错的工具，不过国内用一般的浏览器估计不行吧？

*[[维库|http://www.wikilib.com/wiki/%E9%A6%96%E9%A1%B5]]，一个中文的wiki，关注一下

*Harvard Business School 出的一份新的研究报告（pdf文档），[[Information Technology Ecosystem Health and Performance|http://www.hbs.edu/research/pdf/06-034.pdf]]提出了“信息技术生态系统”（information technology ecosystem）这一概念，并有简要的历史和现状分析，认为，ITE经历了衰退之后，从21世纪开始将迎来复苏。
**今天有好几篇的哈佛商学院报告：[[Information Dispersion and Auction Prices|http://www.hbs.edu/research/pdf/06-011.pdf]]、[[Effects of Task Difficulty on Use of Advice|http://www.hbs.edu/research/pdf/06-019.pdf]]、[[Economic and Technical Drivers of Technology Choice: Browsers|http://www.hbs.edu/research/pdf/06-008.pdf]]，估计不久的中文版商业周刊会有些翻译吧？

*[[Richard Poynder|http://poynder.blogspot.com/]]又一个与[[ Richard Stallman|http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Stallman]]的[[访谈|http://poynder.blogspot.com/2006/03/interview-with-richard-stallman.html]]，后者是[[自由软件运动（ Free Software Movement）|http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_software_movement]]和自由软件基金（Free Software Foundation）的创建者，这个访谈有全文pdf格式下载。

*[[riya|http://riya.com]]是一个能自动识别照片中的人的服务，你给某个人的照片添加了一个tag，它就能自动找出所有有这个人的照片，哇！好像有点恐怖哦！

*William Y. Arms的[[digital library|http://dlist.sir.arizona.edu/1090/]]一书可以OA了，不过是2000年的版本呢

*[[Critical Information Studies: A Bibliographic Manifesto|http://www.nyu.edu/classes/siva/archives/002930.html]]，好像值得研究！
**CIS interrogates the structures, functions, habits, norms, and practices that guide global flows of information and cultural elements. Instead of being concerned merely with one's right to speak (or sing or publish), CIS asks questions about access, costs, and chilling effects on, within, and among audiences, citizens, emerging cultural creators, indigenous cultural groups, teachers, and students. Central to these issues is the idea of ‘semiotic democracy’, or the ability of citizens to employ the signs and symbols ubiquitous in their environments in manners that they determine.
**Economists, sociologists, linguists, anthropologists, ethnomusicologists, communication scholars, lawyers, computer scientists, philosophers, and librarians have all contributed to this emerging field. Critical Information Studies interrogates the structures, functions, habits, norms, and practices that guide global flows of information and cultural elements. Instead of being concerned merely with one’s right to speak (or sing or publish), Critical Information Studies asks questions about access, costs, and chilling effects on, within, and among audiences, citizens, emerging cultural creators, indigenous cultural groups, teachers, and students. Central to these issues is the idea of “semiotic democracy,” the ability of citizens to employ the signs and symbols ubiquitous in their environments in manners that they determine.[[来源于此|http://www.iptablog.org/2004/03/19/critical_information_studies.html]]
**[[Ron Day|http://www.lisp.wayne.edu/~ai2398/]]好像是这个方面的专家
http://h2obeta.law.harvard.edu/70560#ancestorsPlaylists，先记下这个

/***
|''Name''|TiddlySpaceBackstage|
|''Version''|0.8.0|
|''Description''|Provides a TiddlySpace version of the backstage and a homeLink macro|
|''Status''|@@beta@@|
|''Contributors''|Jon Lister, Jon Robson, Colm Britton|
|''Source''|http://github.com/TiddlySpace/tiddlyspace/raw/master/src/plugins/TiddlySpaceBackstage.js|
|''Requires''|TiddlySpaceConfig ImageMacroPlugin TiddlySpaceViewTypes|
!StyleSheet
.tiddler .error.annotation .button{
	display: inline-block;
}

#backstageArea {
	z-index: 49;
	color: white;
	background-color: black;
	background: -webkit-gradient(linear,left bottom,left top,color-stop(0, #222),color-stop(0.5, #333),color-stop(1, #555));
	background: -moz-linear-gradient(center bottom,#222 0%, #333 50%, #555 100%);
	filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorstr=#ff555555, endColorstr=#ff222222);
	-ms-filter: "progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorstr=#ff555555, endColorstr=#ff222222)";
	height: 25px;
	padding: 0;
}

#backstageButton {
	overflow: hidden;
}

#backstageButton #backstageShow,
#backstageButton #backstageHide {
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px;
}

#backstageButton #backstageShow:hover,
#backstageButton #backstageHide:hover {
	background: none;
	color: none;
}

#backstageButton img,
#backstageButton svg {
	width: 24px;
	height: 24px;
}

#messageArea {
	top: 50px;
}

#backstageToolbar {
	position: relative;
}

#backstageArea a {
	padding: 0px;
	margin-left: 0px;
	color: white;
	background: none;
}

#backstageArea a:hover {
	background-color: white;
}

#backstage ol,
#backstage ul {
	padding: auto;
}

#backstageButton a {
	margin: 0;
}

.backstagePanelBody ul {
	padding: 5px;
	margin: 5px;
}

#backstage #backstagePanel {
	margin-left: 5%;
	padding: 0em;
	margin-right: 5%;
}

#backstageToolbar a {
	position: relative;
}

#backstageArea a.backstageSelTab,
#backstageToolbar .backstageTask {
	line-height: 25px;
	color: #767676;
}

.backstageTask .externalImage,
.backstageTask .image {
	display: inline;
}

#backstageToolbar a span {
	z-index: 2;
}

a.backstageTask {
	display: inline;
        margin-left: 1em !important;
}

.backstagePanelBody .button {
	display: inline-block;
	margin-right: 10px;
}

.backstagePanelBody {
	margin: 0 0 0 0.6em;
	padding: 0.4em 0.5em 1px 0.5em;
}

#backstage table {
	margin: auto;
}

#backstage .wizard table {
	border: 0px;
	margin: 0;
}

#backstage div  li.listLink {
	border: 0px;
	width: 78%;
	font-size: 0.7em;
}

#backstage div li.listTitle {
	font-weight: bold;
	text-decoration: underline;
	font-size: 1em;
	background: #ccc;
	width: 100%;
}

#backstage fieldset {
	border: solid 1px [[ColorPalette::Background]];
}

#backstage .viewer table,#backstage table.twtable {
	border: 0px;
}

#backstageToolbar img {
	padding: 0;
}

#backstage .wizard,
#backstage .wizardFooter {
	background: none;
}

.viewer td, .viewer tr, .twtable td, .twtable tr {
	border: 1px solid #eee;
}

#backstage .inlineList ul li {
	background-color: [[ColorPalette::Background]];
	border: solid 1px [[ColorPalette::TertiaryMid]];
	display: block;
	float: left;
	list-style: none;
	margin-right: 1em;
	padding: 0.5em;
}

.backstageClear, .inlineList form {
	clear: both;
	display: block;
	margin-top: 3em;
}

.tiddlyspaceMenu {
	text-align: center;
}

span.chunkyButton {
	display: inline-block;
	padding: 0;
	margin: 0;
	border: solid 2px #000;
	background-color: #04b;
}

span.chunkyButton a.button, span.chunkyButton a:active.button {
	white-space: nowrap;
	font-weight: bold;
	font-size: 1.8em;
	color: #fff;
	text-align: center;
	padding: 0.5em 0.5em;
	margin: 0;
	border-style: none;
	display: block;
}

span.chunkyButton:hover {
	background-color: #014;
}

span.chunkyButton a.button:hover {
	border-style: none;
	background: none;
	color: #fff;
}

#backstage .unpluggedSpaceTab .wizard,
.unpluggedSpaceTab .wizard {
	background: white;
	border: 2px solid #CCC;
	padding: 5px;
}

.syncKey .keyItem {
	border: 1px solid black;
	display: inline-block;
	margin: 0.2em;
	padding: 0.1em 0.1em 0.1em 0.1em;
}

.keyHeading {
	font-size: 2em;
	font-weight: bold;
	margin: 0.4em 0em -0.2em;
}

.unpluggedSpaceTab .putToServer,
.unpluggedSpaceTab .notChanged {
	display: none;
}

.tiddlyspaceMenu ul {
	margin: 0;
	padding: 0;
}

.tiddlyspaceMenu ul li {
	list-style: none;
}

.unsyncedChanges .unsyncedList {
	display: block;
}

.unsyncedList {
	display: none;
}
!Code
***/
//{{{
(function ($) {
    var name = "StyleSheet" + tiddler.title;
    config.shadowTiddlers[name] = "/*{{{*/\n%0\n/*}}}*/".
        format(store.getTiddlerText(tiddler.title + "##StyleSheet")); // this accesses the StyleSheet section of the current tiddler (the plugin that contains it)
    store.addNotification(name, refreshStyles);

    if (!config.extensions.tiddlyweb.status.tiddlyspace_version) { // unplugged
        config.extensions.tiddlyweb.status.tiddlyspace_version = "<unknown>";
        config.extensions.tiddlyweb.status.server_host = {
            url:config.extensions.tiddlyweb.host }; // TiddlySpaceLinkPlugin expects this
    }
    var disabled_tasks_for_nonmembers = ["tiddlers", "plugins", "batch", "sync"];

    var tweb = config.extensions.tiddlyweb;
    var tiddlyspace = config.extensions.tiddlyspace;
    var currentSpace = tiddlyspace.currentSpace.name;
    var imageMacro = config.macros.image;

    if (config.options.chkBackstage === undefined) {
        config.options.chkBackstage = false;
    }

// Set up Backstage
    config.tasks = {};
    config.tasks.status = {
        text:"status",
        tooltip:"TiddlySpace Info",
        content:"<<tiddler Backstage##Menu>>"
    };
    config.tasks.tiddlers = {
        text:"tiddlers",
        tooltip:"tiddlers control panel",
        content:"<<tiddler Backstage##BackstageTiddlers>>"
    };
    config.tasks.plugins = {
        text:"plugins",
        tooltip:"Manage installed plugins",
        content:"<<tiddler Backstage##Plugins>>"
    };
    config.tasks.batch = {
        text:"batch",
        tooltip:"Batch manage public/private tiddlers",
        content:"<<tiddler Backstage##BatchOps>>"
    };
    config.tasks.tweaks = {
        text:"tweaks",
        tooltip:"Tweak TiddlyWiki behaviors",
        content:"<<tiddler Backstage##Tweaks>>"
    };
    config.tasks.exportTiddlers = {
        text:"import/export",
        tooltip:"Import/export tiddlers from/to a TiddlyWiki",
        content:"<<tiddler Backstage##ImportExport>>"
    };
    config.tasks.sync = {
        text:"sync",
        tooltip:"Check Sync status",
        content:"<<tiddler Backstage##SpaceUnplugged>>"
    };

    if (window.location.protocol === "file:") {
        config.unplugged = true;
    }

    config.backstageTasks = ["status", "tiddlers", "plugins",
        "batch", "tweaks", "exportTiddlers", "sync"];

    config.messages.backstage.prompt = "";
// initialize state
    var _show = backstage.show;
    backstage.show = function () {
        // selectively hide backstage tasks and tabs based on user status
        var tasks = $("#backstageToolbar .backstageTask").show();
        var bs = backstage.tiddlyspace;
        if (!config.unplugged) {
            tweb.getUserInfo(function (user) {
                if (user.anon) {
                    jQuery.each(disabled_tasks_for_nonmembers, function (i, task) {
                        var taskIndex = config.backstageTasks.indexOf(task);
                        if (taskIndex !== -1) {
                            config.backstageTasks.splice(taskIndex, 1);
                        }
                    });
                    config.messages.memberStatus = bs.locale.loggedout;
                } else {
                    config.messages.memberStatus = readOnly ?
                        bs.locale.nonmember : bs.locale.member;
                }
            });
        } else {
            config.messages.memberStatus = bs.locale.unplugged;
        }

        // display backstage
        return _show.apply(this, arguments);
    };
    if (readOnly) {
        jQuery.each(disabled_tasks_for_nonmembers, function (i, task) {
            var taskIndex = config.backstageTasks.indexOf(task);
            if (taskIndex !== -1) {
                config.backstageTasks.splice(taskIndex, 1);
            }
        });
    }

    var tasks = config.tasks;
    var commonUrl = "/bags/common/tiddlers/%0";

    backstage.tiddlyspace = {
        locale:{
            member:"You are a member of this space.",
            nonmember:"You are not a member of this space.",
            loggedout:"You are currently logged out of TiddlySpace.",
            unplugged:"You are unplugged."
        },
        showButton:function () {
            var showBtn = $("#backstageShow")[0];
            var altText = $(showBtn).text();
            $(showBtn).empty();
            imageMacro.renderImage(showBtn, "backstage.svg",
                { altImage:commonUrl.format("backstage.png"), alt:altText});
        },
        hideButton:function () {
            var hideBtn = $("#backstageHide")[0];
            var altText = $(hideBtn).text();
            $(hideBtn).empty();
            imageMacro.renderImage(hideBtn, "close.svg",
                { altImage:commonUrl.format("close.png"), alt:altText, width:24, height:24 });
        }
    };

    var _init = backstage.init;
    backstage.init = function () {
        _init.apply(this, arguments);
        var init = function (user) {
            var bs = backstage.tiddlyspace;
            bs.showButton();
            bs.hideButton();
        };
        tweb.getUserInfo(init);
    };

    var home = config.macros.homeLink = {
        locale:{
            linkText:"your home space"
        },
        handler:function (place) {
            var container = $("<span />").appendTo(place)[0];
            tweb.getUserInfo(function (user) {
                if (!user.anon && user.name !== currentSpace) {
                    createSpaceLink(container, user.name, null, home.locale.linkText);
                }
            });
        }
    };

    config.macros.exportSpace = {
        handler:function (place, macroName, params) {
            var filename = params[0] ||
                "/tiddlers.wiki?download=%0.html".format(currentSpace);
            $('<a class="button">download</a>').// XXX: i18n
                attr("href", filename).appendTo(place);
        }
    };

}(jQuery));
//}}}

XRCaUDGdAOQRP1QyUvkvkBHwrBmpXGa/cPBj8f0yYsTSAtMJwJTXDE0X5kIG3AWgBOXJmZh/xFuKgukE4AeCT/zuaaRO+78zN5BC0zfcOghPVTfF+AD8HQ3iD9MJ6D79NTCfwVHnFWNqaBz5gIzn+gQaOd9vUB0eC2nwGTGUxKRJCaMX/3RyuaTgw+AGDoDFF4n/dvC5StWn7npua09iUMWjkkJgfirnodZ0gu1Vs17iuvdl8+4A8/r5/6QSCJ0oWfX/A3UKXhQwWVptAAAAAElFTkSuQmCC
[[信息管理学|http://gcsim.tiddlyspace.com]]
[[信息技术学科导论|http://info-tech.tiddlyspace.com]]
[[信息存储与检索|http://info-orga.tiddlyspace.com]]
[[科学研究方法与论文写作|http://paper.tiddlyspace.com/]]
Original:http://poynder.blogspot.com/2006/03/where-is-open-access-foundation.html

While the term Open Access (OA) has its origins in the 2002 Budapest Open Access Initiative (BOAI), the concept and practice of OA has been around for at least fifteen years. Yet today there is no single universally agreed definition of OA. Not only is this unsatisfactory, but it is allowing opponents and foot-draggers to dilute OA's purpose. What the OA movement needs, suggests Richard Poynder, is a canonical definition of OA and an official organisation charged with overseeing and certifying OA initiatives.

Recently I received a press release from The Biochemical Society informing me that the entire back archive of the Society’s flagship journal the Biochemical Journal (BJ) had been digitised and is now freely available online.

As a result all 392 copies of the journal published since its launch in 1906 (340,000 pages) are now freely available on the Web. This cornucopia, the press release added, includes seminal papers that have “shaped the face of modern cellular and molecular biology”.

There is no doubt that this valuable addition to the corpus of freely available biochemical research is a welcome development, and everyone who helped to make it happen should be applauded — not least the Wellcome Trust and JISC (Joint Information Systems Committee), who provided funding for the project.

Open Access?

However, the news prompted me to wonder how (if at all) the project would further the aims and objectives of the Open Access Movement. After all, the primary focus of OA is to make newly published research freely available on the Web, not historical backfiles.

I was also not clear whether BJ is itself an open access journal. So I emailed the PR Company that had sent me the press release to find out. A short while later I received the answer: “I've had a chat with Audrey McCulloch at the Biochemical Society and she confirms that the Biochemical Journal is indeed an open access journal.”

This surprised me because when I looked at the BJ web site I found a page containing a long list of subscription options. These indicated that it costs from £1,630.00 to £2,118.00 a year to subscribe to BJ.

Of course, there is no reason why a publisher should not charge a subscription for its print journal while making its papers freely available on the Web. Nor is there any reason to assume that people would not subscribe to a print journal in such circumstances. Looking at the BJ website, however, this did not seem to be the case.

As I was scratching my head over this I received an e-mail from Audrey McCulloch herself. “Perhaps I should clarify in what sense BJ is an 'open access' journal,” she wrote. “As soon as a manuscript is accepted for publication, the raw manuscript (as submitted to us by the author) is published online as an 'Immediate Publication'. You can find further details of this at http://www.biochemj.org/bj/imps/toc.htm. These [preprints] are freely available."

She continued: "Authors manuscripts then go through the copyediting, proofreading, typesetting and other processes and are published in print and online in journal issues. These 'value-added' publications are subscription-only for six months after they are published, and then made freely available."

So this means, I asked, that preprints are open access, but published articles are only available to paying subscribers? "Yes, that's correct,” confirmed McCulloch. “The typeset (value-added) articles are Toll Access [TA] for the first six months after publication only. The immediate publications remain freely available at all times (i.e. access to these is not turned off during the six months toll-only access to the typeset articles).”

In other words, the BJ backfile includes everything the journal has published up to six months ago.

Somewhat slippery definition

But this struck me as a somewhat slippery definition of an OA journal. After all, OA journals make the final PDF of articles they publish available online immediately, not six months after publication.

However, looking at the BJ web site I could see that its authors were also encouraged to self-archive their papers.

As BJ's FAQ puts it, if you publish a paper in the journal you can “after obtaining our permission (which would not be withheld unreasonably) and provided that the journal is acknowledged as the original source .. [mount] .. the PDF file of the electronic version of your article on your personal web site, provided you include the following statement: 'Mounted on the Internet with permission from Portland Press (year of publication)'".

(Portland Press is the wholly owned publishing subsidiary of The Biochemical Society and publisher of BJ).

In other words, BJ is a green journal, and a liberal one at that. Indeed, some OA advocates would argue that BJ's self-archiving policy is sufficient in itself.

But while this makes BJ a green journal, it is inaccurate to describe it as an OA (i.e. gold) journal. (See here for further details on the distinction between green and gold OA).

After all, if we accept that BJ is an OA journal because it allows self-archiving, because it releases the final PDF on the Web on an embargoed basis, or because it makes preprints freely available on the Web, then we surely have to conclude that many — if not all — the 93% of journals that currently endorse author self-archiving are also OA journals, including those published by the largest scholarly publisher, Reed Elsevier.

What is an OA journal?

What do we conclude from this? I think we can confidently infer that the Biochemical Society's characterisation of BJ as an OA journal was not intended to mislead me, but simply further evidence (if it were needed) that many people continue to be confused about OA.

Indeed, OA advocates themselves are still puzzling over definitions and labels. Last week, for instance, Springer's Jan Velterop wondered aloud on his blog what constitutes an OA journal. Are they, he asked, "journals that publish OA articles, or journals that publish only OA articles?"

The same question, he said, applies when seeking to define an open access publisher. After all, he said, if one restricts the term to those who only publish OA papers "one risks overlooking — no, one overlooks — all the open access articles that are published in journals that are not exclusively open access."

"Good point," responded OA advocate Peter Suber on his blog. "The BMC [BioMed Central] journals, for example, are unmistakably OA, but most provide OA only to their original research articles, not to their review articles."

Exploring the issue further, Suber added, "One property of OA journals is that they provide OA to their OA articles themselves and don't merely permit authors to do it through OA archiving. But that doesn't settle the question whether a certain portion of a journal's articles must be OA for the journal itself to be considered OA."

He continued, "It would be tempting to conclude that 'full OA journals' and 'hybrid OA journals' differ only in degree, not in kind. But that's not quite accurate either, since there's an important difference, in kind, between journals who let authors choose between OA and TA and journals that have already decided to make all their articles (of a certain kind) OA."

How, I wondered, would self-archiving advocate Stevan Harnad answer Velterop's questions. "I think a fairer and more logical statement is that there are OA publishers, TA publishers, and hybrid OA/TA publishers," he replied. "However, I would insist that a publisher that makes all his articles OA online is a 100% OA publisher even if he still sells TA paper subscriptions, since OA isn't and never was, about free access to paper editions."

He added, "the target content for OA, by the way, is only peer-reviewed research articles, not all articles, nor even all articles that appear in peer-reviewed journals: journals like Science and Nature , after all, publish commissioned news items and reviews too, by staff writers."

We might usefully add here that an OA journal also makes its papers freely available immediately, not (à la BJ) six months after publication — but more on that later.

Clearly there is an ongoing debate here. But Velterop, of course, has his own agenda. He was appointed Director of Open Access at Springer last year, and so is clearly keen both to promote Springer's Open Choice initiative, and to stress Springer's OA-friendliness.

Indeed, those with a more suspicious nature may be inclined to conclude that Velterop would dearly love to redefine OA to better suit the needs of his new employer.

What is certain is that as a former publisher at BioMed Central — and long-time OA advocate — Velterop understands the issues only too well. As such he was surely not posing his questions purely in a spirit of philosophical enquiry.

All things to all men

What is also clear is that however benign the Biochemical Society's misrepresentation of BJ as an OA journal, and however exploratory Velterop's comments may have been, there are some scholarly publishers — and those who represent publishers' interests — who are more than happy to exploit the current ambiguities surrounding OA.

In fact, the signs have been there for some time. I personally drew attention to the issue two and a half years ago, and suggested that we were about to go through a period in which OA would come to mean "all things to all men".

Shortly thereafter, an anonymous poster on the American Scientist Open Access Forum wondered why Nature Immunology was using the term open access on its website without apparent justification. (A reference that was subsequently removed).

And as time passes, so publisher attempts to appropriate OA have increased both in frequency and egregiousness.

Last March, for instance, ACS (the American Chemical Society) announced a new policy in which it said it planned to “post, for public accessibility 12 months after publication, the peer-reviewed version of authors' manuscripts on the National Library of Medicine's PubMed Central."

The announcement was a pre-emptive response to the impending US National Institutes of Health (NIH) policy “on enhancing public access to archived publications resulting from NIH-funded research"; a policy intended to encourage NIH-funded researchers to self-archive their papers in PubMed Central.

ACS presented its own policy statement as an altruistic initiative designed to relieve authors of the "administrative burden of compliance", and as a "method of further opening access to its content."

Redefining Open Access

In reality, however, in offering to archive authors' papers for them, ACS was seeking to limit the number of authors who might self-archive their papers earlier than 12 months (since the NIH had requested they do so "as soon as possible").

In short, while implying that it was embracing and supporting Open Access, ACS was deliberately acting against the spirit of the NIH policy, and implying that embargoed access was the same as Open Access — a tactic I discussed at the time.

The fact is, however, that ACS remains one of the most obdurate opponents of OA. Unlike 93% of scholarly journals, for instance, ACS journals still insist that their authors sign a Copyright Transfer Agreement (CTA) that requires them to give up the right to self-archive their papers. Specifically, it states that "Authors/employers may [only] post the title of the paper, abstract (no other text), tables, and figures of their own papers on their own Web sites, and include these items in their own scholarly, research papers."

Crucially, there is no mention in the CTA of PubMed Central or the NIH policy. As such, most researchers signing it will presumably assume that they are also agreeing not to archive their papers in PubMed Central.

Nor is ACS the only scholarly publisher intent on making embargoed access synonymous with Open Access. Shortly before the ACS statement, for instance, the Nature Publishing Group (NPG) announced that it would encourage its authors "to submit the author's version of the accepted, peer-reviewed manuscript to their relevant funding body's archive, for release six months after publication."

NPG added that "authors will also be encouraged to archive their version of the manuscript in their institution's repositories (as well as on their personal web sites), also six months after the original publication."

While OA advocates greeted the NPG announcement with enthusiasm some later saw NPG's weasel words for what they were. Since NPG had previously encouraged authors to self-archive immediately on publication, NPG was in reality introducing a six-month embargo where no embargo previously existed — a move Harnad immediately dubbed "Back-Sliding."

Delayed open access publisher

In short, as publishers are coming under increasing pressure to make concessions to OA they are seeking to redefine it, both by diluting the definition of what an OA journal is, and by introducing self-archiving embargoes.

To be fair, there are two ways of interpreting this: one is that publishers are simply trying to ensure a gradual and orderly transition from Toll Access to Open Access: another is that they have embarked on a campaign intended to emasculate OA.

Following the behaviour of the Royal Society last December, however, some have concluded that the latter explanation is more likely. Specifically, the Society made the meaningless claim that it was a “delayed open access publisher" — on the grounds that it makes its papers freely available 12 months after publication.

This claim was viewed in a particularly uncharitable light since the Society made it after receiving an Open Letter from 42 disgruntled fellows (a number that has subsequently grown to 64, including 6 Nobel prize-winners) strongly objecting to a position statement the Society had published the month before.

Widely perceived as an attack on OA, the Society's position statement was undoubtedly an attempt to derail the draft proposal published last June by Research Councils UK (RCUK). This envisaged mandating publicly-funded researchers in the UK to self-archive their published papers in institutional repositories.

Unsurprisingly, the Society's self-definition was greeted with considerable derision by open access advocates. “There is no such thing as 'delayed open access publishing', otherwise all publishers are 'delayed open access publishers', some merely having very long delay periods, corresponding to human mortality and the heat death of the universe," commented Harnad sarcastically. "The Royal Society, like all non-OA publishers, is an embargoed-access publisher."

On reflection, Harnad conceded that since the Royal Society allows authors to self-archive their papers in an institutional OA repository it too is a green publisher. However, since only 15% of authors do currently self-archive, the Society is clearly reluctant to make it mandatory.

Indeed, the Society's stratagem may not have been without some effect. At the time of writing, no progress has yet been made with the RCUK proposal, which has missed a number of deadlines for implementation.

Wiggle room

But perhaps we should not be too critical of publishers. Rightly or wrongly they believe that OA poses a significant threat to their income, and they are understandably keen to protect that income.

Indeed, one could justifiably argue that the OA movement has only itself to blame for the current situation, since it has signally failed to produce a canonical definition of OA.

Thus while there have been a number of statements and declarations about OA — including the 2002 Budapest Open Access Initiative, the 2003 Berlin Declaration on Open Access to Knowledge in the Sciences and Humanities, and the Bethesda Statement on Open Access Publishing — these all describe OA in slightly different ways. In addition, there is the BioMed Central Open Access Charter and the Public Library of Science [PLoS] definition of OA, both of which are different again.

And OA advocates have never sought to amalgamate these various descriptions in order to produce a single universal statement of what OA is, and what it entails.

True, in 2003 Suber made an unofficial attempt, but this tends to highlight the differences, rather than the similarities. Moreover, he omitted to include the Berlin Declaration in his analysis.

OA advocates often stress that the various definitions of OA agree on the fundamentals, but it is clear that the absence of a canonical definition is a source of considerable confusion, and leads to frequent factional sniping amongst OA advocates.

Crucially, this state of affairs allows publishers to mix and match different aspects of the various definitions in order to overplay their OA credentials. In seeking to talk up Springer's Open Choice, for instance, Velterop referred not to the most widely-cited definition outlined in the BOAI, but to the Bethesda Statement — because, as Velterop pointed out, the Bethesda Statement "carries the following rider: 'Open access is a property of individual works, not necessarily journals or publishers.'"

In other words, the lack of a single definitive description of OA also gives publishers and OA opponents wiggle room to seek to redefine OA for their own purposes.

Regrettable oversight

There is perhaps no better example of the risks inherent in this vagueness than the way that it is allowing publishers to equate embargoed access with Open Access. After all, since the OA movement has not sufficiently stressed that OA implies immediate access, it is often difficult to challenge such claims.

The BOAI, for instance, states that the prerequisite for OA is the "free availability [of scholarly papers] on the public internet, permitting any users to read, download, copy, distribute, print, search, or link to the full texts of these articles, crawl them for indexing, pass them as data to software, or use them for any other lawful purpose, without financial, legal, or technical barriers other than those inseparable from gaining access to the internet itself."

This description makes no mention of the need for "immediate" access. (Neither does the Berlin Declaration).

Since the BOAI description is the most often cited, the failure to stress immediacy, says Harnad, was a regrettable oversight.

Again, publishers have been happy to exploit this lack of clarity. In an article in Serials Review last year, for instance, Chief Executive of the Association of Learned and Professional Society Publishers Sally Morris described OA simply as "free, unrestricted access (to primary research articles) for everyone."

Aware of the growing risks of this lack of clarity, last year Harnad called on the BOAI signatories "to make explicit what was already implicit" in the BOAI.

In other words, he said, they should amend the BOAI statement to stress that OA "must be now and must be permanent (not, for example, a feature that is provided for an instant, a century from now).”

Why does immediacy matter? Its importance will, of course, depend on the discipline. But in the case of the biomedical sciences (the arena in which much of the battle for OA is currently being fought out) access to the latest research as quickly as possible is widely held to be essential.

No official organisation

Harnad's call for clarification, however, fell on deaf ears. But that is hardly surprising, since the ambiguity surrounding OA is symptomatic of a more serious problem: the absence of any central OA body to oversee and direct the movement.

Who, after all, could have usefully responded to Harnad's request? Even had the signatories of the BOAI heeded it, they would not have been able to legislate for the OA movement as a whole.

For unlike those in the Open Source Movement (who in 1998 created the Open Source Initiative [OSI]), OA advocates have resisted the creation of an umbrella organisation, for fear that it would lead to factional infighting, and so slow the progress of OA.

But is this rational? After all, the Open Source Movement suffers from factionalism and infighting too. One would only have had to monitor, say, the OSI's license-discuss list during last year's debate on licence proliferation to see how divided the movement can be, and how heated discussions can become.

Indeed, there can be few movements that have suffered more from internecine strife than has the Open Source Movement. What better example can there be than the oft-cited e-mail threat Eric Raymond sent to Bruce Perens in 1999. While Perens clearly exaggerated Raymond's message (implying that he feared Raymond might shoot him), the incident demonstrates just how inflamed discussion about open source software can become.

Yet despite this factionalism, and despite the insults and abuse, OSI has achieved a huge amount in the six years since it was established. A quick glance at its history is enough to see how successful an advocacy organisation it has been.

It has also produced a canonical definition of open source software, and it plays a vital role in certifying open source software licences.

Taking ownership

The OA movement then could surely only benefit from emulating the Open Source Movement.

Wouldn’t it be good, for instance, if there were an OA body able to certify anyone wanting to promote themselves as an OA publisher?

Likewise, wouldn’t it be great if there were an official body able to scrutinise publishers' self-archiving policies, and award a seal of approval?

And wouldn't it be easier to attract funding if there were a central non-profit OA organisation?

For while both the Open Society Institute and JISC have proved generous and enlightened benefactors, the current situation is one in which external organisations are deciding where funding should be directed, and who should benefit. As such, they are making important strategic decisions that might be better made by the movement itself.

Moreover, with so many worthy causes in need of support, it is surely only a matter of time before these organisations decide to redirect their funds elsewhere — possibly before the movement has succeeded in its objectives.

When I interviewed the Open Society Institute's Melissa Hagemann last June, for instance, she pointed out that while the Open Society Institute had decided to extend its support for OA beyond the three years initially envisaged, there has never been any wish to "claim ownership" of the movement. "Our intention from the beginning was to provide seed funding, and to help to launch a broad-based movement." In other words, sooner or later, the Open Society Institute will move on.

The fact is that OA advocates have failed to claim ownership of their own movement; and they have not done so out of fear that they might unleash a wave of self-destructive infighting (as if infighting didn’t already take place). But unless they do so soon they risk the greater danger that opponents and foot-draggers will appropriate the movement, and emasculate it in the process.

Right now what the OA movement needs more than anything else is greater clarity, and a unified response to those who are trying to subvert it. But where is the Open Access Foundation that can provide this?
